content_list.subtitle: Solo Stove by Yukon: Key Specs

content_list.content:
It's reasonable to assume that customers of the Yukon stove will have strong opinions on its appearance. This fire pit may serve as the focal point of the arrangement for certain people. Others may have the impression that the drum of a dryer has been removed and positioned upright as if someone had done so deliberately. You wouldn't be completely off base there, but we do know this: the fact that the Yukon is composed of stainless steel indicates that it will be able to withstand the weather well.

If sufficient room is around all sides of the Solo Stove Yukon, it may also be installed in an underground fire pit. The required amount of clearance is between four and six inches.


The Yukon is segmented into layers to ensure that the fuel you use undergoes the most efficient and effective burning process possible. Your fuel is placed on an ingeniously perforated base plate, and the burn chamber is located at the very top of the device.



Underneath is ashes pan, which has two purposes: it protects the ground below from the heat, and it also assists in maintaining the separation between your combustible materials and the byproducts of their combustion. Compared to other kinds of fire pits, the Solo Stove's ventilation design reportedly results in a far higher percentage of wood being reduced to ash, making cleanup a lot simpler.
content_list.subtitle: Solo Stove by Yukon: Design

content_list.content:
This structure has an ingenious airflow arrangement. The Yukon intended to suck oxygen via the ring of perforations on the bottom of its outer layer, which supplies ample oxygenation to the bottom of the fire, blazing on a moving platform around halfway up the primary chambers in the way of a conventional furnace.


The Yukon has a secondary air chamber all the way around its outside borders, so it can also pull air from the top through the openings there. It allows for a subsequent burn, igniting most of the smoke generated by the initial combustion and leading to a larger flame and less distracting carbon clouds.

That is unquestionably a beneficial thing, especially in areas with more wind or a dense population, and it looks wonderful.


The ashes pan is a good addition to the fireplace since it separates the embers and logs from the byproducts of the fire, which results in a cleaner flame; nevertheless, it is not the simplest thing to wash out. The recommendation made by Solo Stove is that you turn the entire thing inverted to get the ash off, which may be a more feasible approach to employ on the Yukon's younger cousins: this thing weighs 38 pounds and is large with it, so make sure to find a friend for help.



However, the fact that it is so large works to its benefit in terms of fuel efficiency. Because the burn chamber of this fire pit can accommodate logs up to 420 centimeters in length, you won't have to resort to using an axe to perform the kind of preparation that is necessary for certain other types of fire pits.

content_list.subtitle: Should you buy Solo Stove by Yukon?

content_list.content:
Does the Solo Stove's outside heat up? I kindled a blaze and allowed it to burn for half an hour. After that, I took the external temperature of the Solo Stove using a laser thermometer. The stove top was approximately 120 degrees Fahrenheit, but the bottom was a chilly 70 degrees. The highest part of the Stove suddenly reached 230 degrees. The top portion of the Stove should thus be avoided when a fire is in progress.


The second objective was the ease with which one may prepare food on the Solo Stove. The grate from my charcoal barbecue worked wonderfully in the Solo Stove. I heated water and toasted bread to evaluate the possibilities of cooking with fire. For me, using a single stove was similar to using a fire pit to prepare meals. It's not easy, but it is certainly possible to do. Particularly if, instead of using open flames, you first reduce wood to embers to use as a cooking medium.


How well does the Solo Stove keep up if left outside for eight months? In a word, quite good. My Solo Stove is protected from the elements and has been kept outside. While the Stove itself appears to be brand new, the rain cover has seen better days.


The rain cover is not torn; it's simply grimy. The fire pit generates little smoke. Your eyes and nose won't moisten or congest from sneezing as you enjoy a campfire. The minimal amount of white ash left at the bottom after a fire also makes cleanup a breeze.


The primary drawback of Solo Stove is the price. It's pricey at roughly $500. The Solo Stove's pricing is on pace with other smokeless options like Bree, while a fire pit will cost you far less to construct.
